Instructions.text: Press the round button beside the FEED stream box to open the Feed view. The stream going from the mine to the flotation circuit is called FEED. It has a certain grade of valuable metal, in our case copper.
Look at the graph. What is the copper grade of this stream?
True and considering it is your first time in this screen, what is the flow rate of the Feed Stream?
That s correct. Even if you have changed it, you could have guessed because flow rate is given by tons per hour.
Are your sure? Then tell me: with a Feed flow rate of 10 t/h, air at 2 cm/s and froth at -10 mm, what is the flow rate of Concentrate Stream (the one which goes from the flotation bank to the bin)?

True. This means that from the 10 tons entering your flotation cell, 2 tons go to the Concentrate (which is the good stuff, that we can process and sell), while the other 8 tons go to the Tailings stream, which we didn't show just to simplify the process.
But going back to the Concentrate subject, as a flotation operator you want to make sure you are producing the right amount of concentrate according to your Feed flow rate.
After all, producing 6 tons of Concentrate out of 6 tons of Feed is very profitable, while producing 6 tons out of 600 hundred tons of Feed will make you bankrupt.
You can check you are doing a good job by finding the CONCENTRATION RATIO. It represents the amount of tons you need to feed the cell in order to produce one ton of concentrate.
For example, if your concentrate flow rate is 1 t/h with a feed flow rate of 10 t/h, your concentration ratio is 10. The cell is producing one ton of concentrate with 10 tons of feed.

Now try this. Check the Concentrate graphs to make sure your Cu recovery is above 80%. Now tell me, what is the Concentrate Ratio of this process?

 Concentration ratio =
Feed flow rate / Concentrate flow rate

Correct. Now press the circle in the mine icon and change the Feed flow rate to around 20. Did the concentration ratio change? 

 Concentration ratio =
Feed flow rate / Concentrate flow rate
Exactly! Cells are usually designed to work with an optimal Concentration Ratio. In the next lessons, we will learn about other performance calculations
